speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hey Cynthia, how have you been doing?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Honestly, not so well.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m sorry to hear that, can you explain why that is the case?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’ve been struggling transferring from my wheelchair to my bed.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How annoying. You said “recently”, can you tell me how many days you have been struggling with this issue.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: The exact amount of days I’m unsure of but it has been getting progressively harder.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: OK. I’ll try my best to help you. So, can you elaborate a little further by telling me what exactly is limiting your ability to transfer from wheelchair to bed.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I no longer have the strength for it.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: The lack of strength, does that have to do with your legs?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, it does.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Has it become impossible to transfer or do you eventually get there?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It’s become impossible. I can’t do it anymore.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Where in the process of transferring does it go wrong? Are you able to stand up from your chair?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can get up a little bit but before I can fully straighten my legs, I end up falling back into my chair.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds very frustrating, has that taken a large toll on you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, it has. I live alone so I’ve had to ask my son to help me out the last few days. Luckily, he lives around the corner but I still feel like I am burdening him.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand. Do you have any other feelings regarding your current condition?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, I only feel bad for my son.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good afternoon ma’am, my name is John. What’s your name?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Good afternoon John, my name is Sarah.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Since this is the first time we meet, is it okay if I ask a few personal questions?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes of course!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: OK. So, how old are and could you describe your living environment.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am 71 years old and for the past 40 years I have been living with my husband.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What did you do for work?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I used to be a data analyst.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Alright, so can you now tell me why you are here today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have been struggling getting out of bed.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m sorry to hear that. Currently, how are you managing to get out of bed?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I get my husband to help me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What part of getting out of bed do you need help with?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have trouble getting myself seated upright. Once I’m seated by the edge of the bed I can get out. It’s getting to that position that is hard.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: And so, your husband helps by pulling you up?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That is correct.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Does your husband help you a lot or do you only need a little assistance.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: He doesn’t help too much but I can’t do it without him.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Has this been difficult for you and your husband?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yeah, it’s been quite tough. I’m afraid that if this were to continue, it will lead to him injuring his back.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Does your husband have issues with his back?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, a lot. He has had many surgeries. Currently he’s doing well but I hope to keep it that way.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand, we’re going to do our best to keep you and your husband healthy.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Thank you, I appreciate that a lot.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hey, my name is Elisabeth, I will be your physiotherapist for today.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hi Elisabeth, my name Susanne, nice to meet you.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Nice to meet you too. How old are you Elisabeth?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am 63 years old.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Alright Susanne, what can I help you with?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have had 2 total knee replacements and feel as if I never fully gained my strength back. It’s been difficult getting up from a seated position.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s unfortunate. So, it’s difficult but not impossible?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yeah, I’m able to stand up but it just costs me a lot of energy.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: If I were to ask you to repeatedly stand up and sit back down, how many times do you reckon you could do it?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I think I could do about 4 back to back.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: And each and everyone one of those feels physically demanding?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yeah, they do.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Purely from out your muscles or do you also get out of breath?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: A bit of both but primarily the muscles.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How do you feel about your situation?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’m afraid of getting old and I feel as if this may be this first signs that I am at that point in my life.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you feel like your age?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No not really, I feel much older than I actually am. I feel as if my body should be much more capable at 63 years old.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I feel for you. We’re going to work on your ability to transfer and that should leave you feeling more capable.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Thank you very much.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hey Michelle how are you today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hi Anastasia, I’m doing pretty well, our physio sessions together have really helped me transfer better.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s great to hear! Last few sessions we worked on floor transfers in case you fall onto the floor. Have you practiced those at home?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, I have. Although, I am having some difficulties with them.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s fine, it’s something new so we will continue to work on that today.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Okay, perfect.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Alright so let’s start off with the difficulties you mentioned having.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yeah, so what’s been happening is when I transfer from my wheelchair down to the ground, everything goes well but at the end I let myself fall a bit too much.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see, do you have the idea that your strength is insufficient?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, I don’t think so, I just think my technique needs some perfecting.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: OK. In a second, we will get to the movements but first I would like to ask some additional questions.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That’s fine by me

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Its now been quite a while since you have had your spinal injury, how has it been adapting to your new way of living.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: At first it was hard, I felt useless, everything I used to be able to do become an impossible task. But luckily now that is no longer the case. Those tasks no longer feel impossible and day by day things are going better.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s wonderful to hear! Let’s keep up the good work and get to practicing those transfers.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Lets do it!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning sir, my name is James, how are you doing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Good morning, my name is Joseph. I’m doing good, and you?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m also doing good. So, I see based on your referral that you had a small stroke a few months ago is that correct?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, that is true.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: OK. I see the reason the doctor referred you was in order to improve your physical condition. We will focus on strength and cardiovascular endurance training. But first, in the file I see you had some issues transferring, is that still the case?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, it’s actually improved a lot.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You don’t find yourself in any situations where you feel unsure of your ability to transfer?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Nope

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You no longer require any assistance?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No not anymore

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Perfect, the transfers itself, are they physically demanding or would you have to do them several times back to back in order to experience any exertion

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, not physically demanding at all, I think after 10 I might feel something.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s great to hear. Is it okay if I ask you some additional questions before we start our training session?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That’s okay.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: After a stroke, I imagine a lot changes in one’s life. How have you experienced this?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I definitely started taking my health more seriously. I’m just so grateful that it was a small stroke. I would hate to be in a wheelchair.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Have you changed your lifestyle at all after the stroke?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I immediately started eating healthier since my high cholesterol was the most likely culprit of my stroke.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Anything else

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, I also started going on walks more often. I felt as if I was inside too much and should appreciate mother nature more often.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi, how are we doing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not so well.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Would you tell me more about it?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I feel weak. I couldn't get out of my bed this morning. I had to wait for my partner to help me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm sorry about that. Could you get up with help?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, but I don't like it. I don't want to rely on others. I need to be able to go at least where I want to go.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I do feel for you. I'm sure it'll get better. Do you need any assistance when you walk?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have a wheelchair. I was able to walk at home a bit with the help of my son, but recently I feel a lot weaker and I need my wheelchair for basically everything. But it is not convenient at home at all. For getting in and out of the wheelchair I depend on my son 100%.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see that. Are you able to do anything with the wheelchair by yourself?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can't. I feel like my legs and arms are too weak to get me up. Especially if where I sit or lie is low, I don't have strength to stand up on my own.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see. So we will need to work on your strength, so you will be less dependant on your son.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That sounds like a good plan. I am sick of feeling so weak.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That's good to know. You mentioned you live with your partner, has she been helpful?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can't live without her now. Thank god he's still strong, but he has bad eyesight. We are supporting each other.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How are you coping with your current situation?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I wish I can grow stronger, a few months ago, I was still able to get up, although struggled a bit. Now I'm sad that I need help for that.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning, I am Annabelle and I will take care of you this morning. What is your name?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Good morning, my name is Heinz.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Nice to meet you Heinz. How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am not doing so good. I am scared of going outside of my bed, because my legs feel so weak.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am sorry to hear that. Do you feel comfortable to leave your bed with a bit of help?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, with a bit of help it is alright. But I really wanna build up my abilities to leave my bed on my own.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Understandable. For this morning I will help you and then we will build up your strength together.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Sounds great. Thank you.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: With which part of getting out of bed do you have the most problems?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Honnestly with putting myself in a seated position.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Why do you think that is the hardest?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I don't trust my abdominal strength, that is why I have the feeling that I will fall over as soon as I am seated.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: And do you feel like you will fall over to the front, back or to one side?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: To the front most parts and a bit to the side.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you have the same feeling when you are standing or is it just like that when you are seated?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: While standing it is even worse because my legs feel so weak.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Are you dependant an your significant other for help?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, so much. And it is so frustrating. I was never a weak person and now I even need help to get out of bed.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How are you coping with this frustration?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Honnestly I cry a lot and need a lot of affection and good words from my partner. Without her I could not do it. She is an angle.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It is good to hear that you have so much support. And I am sure we will get you stronger in the coming weaks so you have it easier leaving your bed.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That would be amazing.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good evening sir. How was your day?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hello. My day was quite nice except for one thing.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Can I ask you what went wrong?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Of course, maybe you can also help me. I don't like to admit it, but getting from standing on to sitting on the toilet is so painful and almost impossible to do on my own. I don't know how to place my arms so I don't put pressure on my abdominal part where it hurts when I use the muscles.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Thank you for sharing your difficulty with that process. We can do it now together and I can show you what the best position is to not tense up your abdominal muscles and then you can try it on your own under my supervision. How does that sound?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Sounds great. Thank you so much.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Now you are standing. How would you proceed further to sit down on the toilet?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I try to slowly lean forward with the help of my rollator and get into kinda a squatting position and then I would feel a bit of pain and with that I am not comfortable so I ask the nurse to help me sit down.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see your problem. Do you not trust the steadiness of your rollator or is the pain that strong that you get scared?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Maybe pain is the wrong word. It is more a new uncomfortable feeling and yes the rollator has wheels so I don't trust that he holds my weight while sitting down.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Okay, I see. I will show you how much you can trust the rollator, because trust me, the brakes are amazing and then you don't need the help of the nurse anymore and you are only dependant on the rollator.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That would be so great, because then I don't need to wait so long to go to the toilet.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you have any help at home?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, I live still alone because my wife just passed away and before I could move in an appartement where there is help, I had to go to the hospital.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Oh no, I am so sorry to hear that. But that means as soon as your out of the hospital you will have help? Or you will still live alone for a bit?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Still alone for a bit. But maybe my son will have the time to help me out.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Please let me know until our next meeting how your situation at home will look like so I can prepare your abilities.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes of course, thank you so much for considering that.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hello. How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am good. Just some minor inconviences, but for the most part I am alright. How are you?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am also good. Thanks for asking. Can you tell me which inconveniences are bothering you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Of course. I have a bit of trouble getting from standing back on my bed into sitting. And I don't wanna ask the nurses for help, because it is so much better than the days before, but I need a tiny bit more help.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand what you mean. We can practice it together so you are more comfortable with that. How does that sound?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Very nice. Like that I don't have to bother anyone.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am sure you are not bothering people if you ask for help. The nurses and I gladly help you.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning, I am Rihanon and I will help you today.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Good morning, that sounds very good. It is not a bad day but I struggel a bit with getting from sitting into laying.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That is lovely to hear. Would you mind telling me what makes it difficult for you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Of course not. I am quite uncomfortable with bending my upper body, so going to on side is a bit harsh on my body and I don't know how I can lay down in any other way.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is it more the bending to the front, side ot back that is harsh on your body?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I think the bending to the side is the most problematic. As soon as I do it, I tense up and then I rather ask the nurse for help, then trying it on my own again. I am quite sure I could do it on my own. Just my head is a bit in the way still.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Great that you can describe it that detailed. So we will work on that today and we will try to get the trust in your body back. Sounds good?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Sounds amazing.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I want to ask you about the situation at home. Do you feel comfortable living alone again?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Almost yes. I only struggel sometimes with laying in bed in the evening if I have done a lot of garden work for example during the day.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How do you cope? Are you calling somebody?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, I am very lucky that my daughter lives across the street and these days she comes over to dinner anyways so she helps me in this situation.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How do you feel about that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: A bit annoyed because I want to be able to do everything alone again, but really lucky because I have such an amazing daugther.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Understandable. I am sure you will soon be independant!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good afternoon. How are you doing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am very good. Thanks for asking. How are you?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am also good. How is your daily live going? Do you have any problems?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Very good to be honnest. I am able to do everything I want to.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds amazing. So you don't feel put back by anything?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not at all. My body feels great and ready to conquer anything.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You told me last time that you still have some problems getting out of your wheelchair. Is that still true?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am very happy to tell you that this is not a problem anymore. Everything is alright.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am very glad to hear that. So you don't have problems anymore with extending your hip?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Nope, all the pain is gone.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: And you did not get any different medication?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, everything worked out on his own. I think the Physiotherapy really helped my hip problem and now the problem is gone.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Amazing! I wanted to ask you about your situation at home and if that improved since you are able to do everything on your own.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Thanks for asking. Actually it is quite nice to not depend on my husband anymore and to finally be able to go everywhere in the house on my own.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds nice. Anything that is bothering you.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I feel a bit overlooked now that I am healthy, my grandchildren don't visit me that much anymore. Which I understand, they all have their own life, but I miss them.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand. But now you can play with your grandkids and not miss out on any activity.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Thank you for the reminder. That is true and it is great.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi, how are we doing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not so well.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Would you tell me more about it?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I feel weak. I couldn't get out of my bed this morning. I had to wait for my partner to help me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm sorry about that. Could you get up with help?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, but I don't like it. I don't want to rely on others. I need to be able to go at least where I want to go.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I do feel for you. I'm sure it'll get better. Do you need any assistance when you walk?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have both rollator and a wheelchair. I was able to walk at home with the rollator, even if just a few steps, but recently, I felt weaker. I tried to get on the wheel chair, but it's not convenient to move around at home. I usually use wheelchair to go outside, but they are not for home. It's not convenient to move around at home.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see that. Are you able to get on the wheelchair by yourself?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can't. I feel like my legs and arms are too weak to get me up. Especially if where I sit or lie is low, I don't have strength to stand up on my own.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see. Is it difficult for you to transfer to the toilet?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: My toilet was adapted. That was fine. I had better support there.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That's good to know. You mentioned you live with your partner, has he/ she been helpful?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can't live without him now. Thank god he's still strong, but he has bad eyesight. We are supporting each other.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How are you coping with your current situation?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I wish I can grow stronger, a few months ago, I was still able to get up, although struggled a bit. Now I'm sad that I need help for theat.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good evening sir. How was your day?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hello. My day was quite nice except for one thing.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Can I ask you what went wrong?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Of course, maybe you can also help me. I don't like to admit it, but getting from standing on to sitting on the toilet is so painful and almost impossible to do on my own. I don't know how to place my arms so I don't put pressure on my abdominal part where it hurts when I use the muscles.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Thank you for sharing your difficulty with that process. We can do it now together and I can show you what the best position is to not tense up your abdominal muscles and then you can try it on your own under my supervision. How does that sound?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Sounds great. Thank you so much.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Now you are standing. How would you proceed further to sit down on the toilet?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I try to slowly lean forward and get into kinda a squatting position and then the pain would shoot in my stomach and I would let myself fall on the toilet because I am not able to hold the position.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see your problem. You don't use your arms at all which means your upper body can only rely on your abdominal muscles. Let me demonstrate how you can protect these.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes of course. Thank you so much.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: So if you are standing in front of the toilet you have two handles next to it. So you get into a bit of a squat position but really not a lot. Then you put both of your hands on the handles and put your weight on the arms and not on stomach. After that you can slowly guide yourself down into a sitting position. Wanna try?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes sure.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you have any help at home?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, I live still alone because my wife just passed away and before I could move in an appartement where there is help, I had to go to the hospital.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Oh no, I am so sorry to hear that. But that means as soon as your out of the hospital you will have help? Or you will still live alone for a bit?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Still alone for a bit. But maybe my son will have the time to help me out.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Please let me know until our next meeting how your situation at home will look like so I can prepare your abilities.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes of course, thank you so much for considering that.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning Theo, how is everything going?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hey, in all honnesty today is a terrible day. Basically everything is getting worse.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Sorry to hear that. Could you tell me what is bothering you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: There are so many things I am not able to do at all. I can't even grab a pen at the moment.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Why is that so difficult?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: My whole hand feels numb and I can't control when I close my fingers into a fist.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is it your right or left hand? I assume it is your dominant side?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes. My dominant hand is my left. It was fine picking up a cup to trink, but as soon as the object was tinier, I could not grab it anymore. My fingers start trembeling and I can't controle the movements anymore. So frustrating.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand. Are you able to carry bigger objects, like your phone?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Phone yes, but not things that are heavier. Then I need to use my right hand or I need to ask for help. I feel like when I use my left hand more the symptoms will get worse and I don't wanna go back to where I was not able to use it at all.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand why you would think that. But actually the more you will use the hand, the more the brain can build up the connection to the muscles again.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: OMG, I had no idea.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is that situation affecting your mental state?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Sooo much, You have no idea. I hate it.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Thank you for sharing that with me. Do you live alone or together with your family?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I live with my husband and our 3year old child. He is my support system. I can't live without him.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How does that make you feel?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Amazing because I have my loved ones around me, but horrible because I am so dependant on him and having a toddler is already challenging enough so I think it can be a bit too much for him sometimes.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Understandable.

speaker: doctor

I can't stop thinking why she would forget about me. Maybe one day, I should tell her a story about who she is everyday, like the movie The Note.

content: ** C: Great. How have you been lately?

content: ** P: Not bad. My eldest kid has come to stayed with for holiday. We're enjoying out time.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good to know! Life's been great for you! Let know if there anything bothering you currently.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: As you know, I live by the river, and I had to ride a small boat to the shore if I want to go anywhere. Now I find it unsafe to get on the boat.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Why do you feel unsafe?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: When I step on the boat, it shakes a bit, and I felt loss of control. It's scary, I never felt this before.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How long has it been?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: a month or so. I almost fell once. After that, I had to have someone holding my hand until I find my balance on the boat.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What about after you get on the boat? Any discomfort?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: All good. I mean I probably can't stand still on a moving boat, but I don't have to. Just going on and off the boat is a problem, I need someone to help now.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see. How do you feel about this change?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It's vey inconvenient. And I don't like it, as, like, this is a sign of me getting older?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It doesn't have to be.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: If you say so, but still I wonder, is there anything I can do about this?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Absolutely. We can schedule a visit and see what we can do to get you back on the boat safely.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Great. Do not go gentle into that good night. I still wanna try.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi Mr. M, how are you today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Nothing special.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You mentioned last time you had difficulty getting on and off the boat. Are you feeling any better?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Much better, I'd say. I did some trainings.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That's good to know. How long have you been training?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: 2 months. about three times a day. As suggested by the physiotherapist.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Congratulaitions, you've achieved a lot. Would you describe to me how you are getting on and off now?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Of course. So when I step onto the boat, it was from a higher platform to a lower one. And my supporting leg was getting weaker, so I always lower my body too quickly.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see. Is that why you lost your balance?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Exactly. So after training, I had better control. And could lower down slowly.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Would you say you're totally able to get on your boat on your own now.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not really, I still need someone to stand next to me. So I can reach to him when I feel I'm losing balance. And sometimes I do. It'd be too risky otherwise.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How do you see you current progress?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I'm basically satisfied. But of course it could be even better if I don't need anyone else to help.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You're right. And happy to see that you're making progress.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Maybe I should keep training and see if I can improve my balance.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: If you're motivated, I'm sure you can still improve.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I'm very optimistic about that.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good moring Mr. M, is everything going OK?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hi, nice to have you calling again. It's been great.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good to know that everything's great. Did you get better with your boat riding?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes and no.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Oh, why's that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I made some adaptations.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What kind of adaptations?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I setup a rail next to the steps, so that I have something to hold on to when I get on and off the boat.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It sounds helpful for you.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It is, for sure, it is. It's just, I realized I'm not getting any better with trainings. I still feel I could lose my balance when I step on my boat. And I always have to ride a boat to the land. So you know, it's safer to make some adaptations.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I agree. You're right. Do you still have difficulty with the hand rail?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not at all. I could go on and off freely. No one has to be wathing over me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That's great news! How do you feel about that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not very well. I did strength trainings, some balance trainings. I thought I should be able to go back to what I was capable of, but I didn't.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand. It's a natural process, but the good side is, you're don't have any troubles with using the boat.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, there's the bright side, but it also means I'm really old now, that I need help with getting on the boat. That feeling sucks. I've spent my life traveling by boat. And now I'm not able to step on the boat without assistance. What's next? I probably can't sit still on the boat.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see your concern, but...

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I know it's more important to be able to use the boat, with adaptations or no, but do you understand this feeling, even if I did everything I could, growing older and weaker is simply inevitable.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi XXX, how are you managing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Terrible. Don't even get me started.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Oh, what's happening?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: There's something wrong with my wheelchair. I have to get it fixed ASAP!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm sure it can be fixed. What's wrong with it?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It got stuck halfway constantly. I was almost thrown out because of the sudden stop!!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm very sorry about that. Were you injured?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: thank god no. If I got hurt, I'll meet you in the court.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: So sorry. Let's solve the problem before that. How long have you been using the wheelchair?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: You'd better do. Why does it matter how long I have been using it? You'll fix it no matter what.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: No worries, sir. We can find a solution in any case. I need to collect necessary information, so that we can help you more efficiently.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Alright. I used it for two years. It's been working fine, but recenly I started to hear wierd noise and today got stuck. And since the incident, I stopped using it for my own safety.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Understood. It's marked down. I'll see what I can do. In the meantime, how would you cope with the situation lately?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can stay at home. It's safe for me to stay home.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How would this make you feel? Staying home for a few days?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It's fine for three days, but no longer than that.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see. Max 3 days at home.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes. Or it's gonna be boring for me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi, Dr. P, haven't been talking to you since you left the hospital. How is everything?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hi Sandy. You're right, It's been a while since I developed you. Let me see if you are smarter than before.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I shall try. You came to visit a neurologist 6 months ago, and diagnosed with Parkinson's. I'm sorry about that.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I noticed some trembling in my hands half a year ago. And I became more clumsy. So I thought, maybe it's time. Parkinson is in my family history.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You are the expert. How has it been for you after the visit?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: You know I love skating. Every Friday night I joined the stakting gathering in Utrecht. I could always make a show for everyone. But not anymore.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I can imagine how tough it must be for you.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes. I used to go to work by skating. Now I can't skate without someone walking by my side. I can still skate, but my legs are out of control sometimes.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It's safer to have someone by your side. How long has it been?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: A year ago. It was during skating when I noticed something went wrong. After that, everything went down quicly. I felt unconfident to make skilful moves at first, and then regular skating became hard to control too. Imagine, within one year.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I feel for you. Could you describe your symptoms?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Now I have all those classic symptoms, tremors, bradykinesia. I haven't been shuffling though, but I guess that won't be far away.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Does these new changes haev any emotional impact on you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can't say no. This is big change to my life, but I was well-prepared. It's in my genes. My father and grandfather all suffered from a quickly-developed Parkinson's.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It's good that you're prepared. And you know a lot about it already.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That's right. I've taking precautions years ago.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you think you can get support from others when necessary?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, I'm lucky on that. I have a very healthy wife. She's been supporting me ever since. I'd be depressed without her.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi there, How are you doing lately?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not too great.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C:What's troubling you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It's getting harder for me to go around.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How do you go around now? With walker, wheelchair? Or do you mean by bus, or bike?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: With my rollator.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Sorry that you had trouble with you rollator. Could tell me your concern?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can't walk outside for long distance anymore, I got tired easily even when just walking at home.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Were you able to walk at home with your rollator?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I still can, but on one hand, I had to be very cautious like walking on the ice. And I tend to rely more on my arms. I don't know if it's a good time for me to use a wheelchair, but I also feel reluctant to do so, cause once I use wheelchair, I might never be able to use a rollator.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand, it's hard to make the decision. Is it difficult for you to keep balance with rollator.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I don't know if balance is the main issue. Maybe it's my legs that are getting weaker.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I completely understand your situation. How are you feeling with that issue?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I'm worried. I live alone, and I intend to keep my life as it is. I don't want to move to the elder home. I don't like being amongst people.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I agree. Your preference should be considered. Do you get enough support from others when you need it?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I don't have children. My partner passed away 2 years sgo. I don't like being around people. I prefer not needing any support from other strangers.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It could be challanging to offer you proper care, and it's important to keep your independence and privacy. Do you think a PT session to assess your living situation and visits of social worker would be of help?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: you may schedule a PT session, but other than that is not necessary.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi, Ms X, how have you been?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: hey, not so well.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Sorry to hear that. Do you have any complaintes?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I don't know what's going on, but I tend to fall recently.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Oh no, how did you fall?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I mean I almost fall when I was walking with my walker.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How many often does it happen?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can recall a few times last month. I buckled for no reasons and my arms were supporting me on the walker, so that I didn't really fall.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How long has it been?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: not very long. Less than 2 months I think. It's scary when it happens, I don't know what's wrong.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand your concern. Have you noticed anything that might trigger those moments?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Maybe uneven surface.. or maybe I was only trying to walk faster, but I'm not sure, but I think I need some more stable assistance now.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see you. How are you feeling with needing more assistentance?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I think it's a natural process. I had a serious emotional hit when I had to use the walker, but now, I feel nothing.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you think it's acceptable for you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It doensn't matter whether I want to accept or not. It just happens.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm sorry about that. Maybe you can schedule a PT session and see what's best for you.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I don't think that's gonna help.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi Mr. B. This is Sandy. Is everything going OK?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hi Sandy. Yes, everything is good. Thanks for. asking.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You started to use a rollator last month, how's it going?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not bad. Life's been so much easier.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Oh, glad to hear that.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I'm glad I made the decision.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Where do you use your rollator now?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Everywere I go. At home, on the streets... I feel a lot bore stable when walking with a rollator.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Great to hear! Have you met any difficulty when using rollator?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: At home, there's a pretty narrow turning. I always got stuck there a bit, but no big deal. I just had to walk slowly.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Not bad. Are you used to walking with this rollator?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, my PT taught me how to use it. I don't have to worry about falling anymroe.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That's a really nice change! How do you feel about that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: This rollator helped me a lot. I was very worried about walking safety before, but not anymore now.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: The rollator supports you.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Right. I also had more outdoor activities recently, since I can go farther now.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It's also a positive change that you have a higher activity level.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, it is. I feel more energetic now.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi Mrs. H how are you today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’m not so good.  It is good weather today but I am stuck in my house the whole day.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: The weather is perfect indeed. Why is that you can not enjoy the weather?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Well, I can't really go out of my house.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Oh, that's sad to hear. Can you tell me more about this?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: So I missed my sister's birthday because I have this sharp pain in my back and I can't really walk more than 10 meters.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: So I missed my sister's birthday because I have this sharp pain in my back and I can't really walk more than 10 meters.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is there anyone that helps you move around?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It is my sister, but as I said today is her birthday so I was planning to visit her

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Are you able to go out of your house at all?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: The way from the bed to the kitchen is already hurting too much

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you think you need assistance?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: The nurse comes to the house to help me with daily chores.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Thats good to hear. What have you been struggling with?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It is har for me to sit up from the bed.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Anything else that is hard?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Going to the toilet is quite difficult as well

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s really unfortunate. How do you feel about not being able to move?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Well, I feel lonely. I am not able to go to the library and meet friends from the book club.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is there anyine who could drive you there?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Maybe I could ask my sister but I do not want to bother her.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good day, Mrs A. How are we feeling today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am okay.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Can you tell me how old you are?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am 65. Oh, sorry, I lied. I am 66 already.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That all right. And what has been bothering you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Well, I want to get out of the house, but it is hard for me to walk long using my crutches.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Why are you using crutches?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I had surgery not so long ago on my hip.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you remember then?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Umm, it was last Thursday. I believe the 11th of March.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Five days ago, right?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Can you tell me more about your ability to move?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have to walk with my crutches around the house. It is annoying.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Are you able to get out of bed by yourself?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, that is not the problem.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is it painful to move?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Well, the hip is stiff and achy.  It is worse in the morning when I go to the bathroom.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That is sad to hear. Is using the bathroom causing any issues?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It is quite hard to open the door, but overall, it is not too bad.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It seems like you can move by yourself. Do you need any assistance to help out at home?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: My daughter brings me groceries because I can't go to the store. Also, my husband has been cooking dinner for the family.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How nice. I was wondering if you have any obstacles at your home that make it harder to move around?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I live on the second floor. I cannot go down by myself because of the stairs.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Does that make you sad?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I want to live my life. I feel like I am stuck at my house.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you have a person to whom you can talk about this?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I talk to my husband, but I do not think he understands my frustration.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You can always reach out for a conversation. I can help with that.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hello, my name is Mrs X. What is your name?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Good afternoon. My name is Mr. Y.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How have you been?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am fine, thank you for asking.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Have you been traveling lately?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Actually, I just went to the market today.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How did you travel?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I walked because it is not that far from where I live.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Was it easy?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I wanted to ride my bike to the market, but my knee is still a little bit stiff.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Can you tell me more about your knee when transporting yourself?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I don’t have any complaints when walking. It's just that if I bike for more than 10 minutes, it starts to ache a tiny bit.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Can you pinpoint a specific part of the knee that hurts?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Umm, I don’t think so. It just hurts all over.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How much does it hurt then you bike? Can you give a number from one to ten, ten being the worst pain and one being no pain?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I would say six.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: And then you walk?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It is okay to walk. I think I can say one.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: And if you walk for a longer time, does that make the pain worse?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Maybe a little bit, but not much.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you have difficulty climbing the stairs?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I do, but I live on the first floor, so I do not have to use them that often.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Okay. How do you feel about your health?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It is annoying that my knee hurts a little. I hope to start biking again.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you think your injury limits you in your social life?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: If I want to go somewhere, it would be easier to bike, but I can use public transport. So I would not say it is limiting me to social gatherings.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you have family that could help you with your recovery?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Well, I live with my wife. She has helped me with household chores. But I always try to help her out as well, now that I am walking without pain.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That is lovely to hear.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning. how are you today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Perfect, thank you for asking. Today, I travelled to Utrecht to see my grandson’s football game.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: So lovely to hear that from you. How was the journey?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It was good. It was my first time driving a car in a very long time.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What stopped you from driving for an extended period?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: After my hip surgery, I was not allowed to drive.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand. And how does the hip feel today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Great. I have no pain in my hip.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Was traveling to your grandson’s football game easy today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: In fact, it was. I had to walk to the car and sit for 30 minutes, but that did not cause any pain or discomfort.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Lovely to hear. Do you have any complaints about your health at this moment?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I do not think so. After the surgery, I was scared I would not be able to move. But I see that I am getting healthier every single day.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How do you feel about your rehabilitation

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am relieved. I did my exercises every day, and now I am even more motivated to work out than ever.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Great news. How does your family feel about your condition?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: My family has been very supportive and helped me with everything I needed. They encourage me to go on walks with them and keep healthy.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Seems like you are happy with your health. Am I right?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, I feel really happy that I can move by myself and I can see my family at important events.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Glad to hear.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C:Good morning how are you doing today? It’s a really nice day.

speaker: patient
content: ** P:Yes, it is a nice day, unfortunately, I could not enjoy the good weather.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C:I’m sorry to hear that. Can you please tell me what is the problem?

speaker: patient
content: ** P:Yeah, I had some pain recently, which is make me not able to do my daily routine.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: oh it’s not nice would you please explain what kind of pain do you have?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes it is a kinda sharp pain radiates from my lower back to my knees and my foot

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: To what extent is this pain in your back affecting your daily routine or daily life?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Quite a lot. I cannot sit in the car; therefore, I’m always at home. For instance, yesterday we wanted to go for a picnic, but it was not possible because we had to use the car.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m sorry to hear that. Can you elaborate on what kind of pain you feel in your lower back?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have pain around my right hip, in a line area like a circle.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Does the pain radiate to your leg?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, but it’s so painful that it makes me unable to move!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I wonder, how do you feel about this situation and your life in general?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: You know, I like being social, and since I usually use the car to commute, this situation upsets me. I haven’t been out of the house for the last two weeks!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I can’t imagine how hard that is. How is your family supporting you these days?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have my wife’s support but she is also affected since she’s staying home with me. our children are trying to visit us as much as they can.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: hi Mrs. D how are you doing? We had your last appointment two weeks ago right?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes it was. It was two weeks ago after my surgery.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: nice how is life going after surgery?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: very better I have less pain and I am gradually getting better.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: hope you are able to enjoy this nice spring winter

speaker: patient
content: ** P: it’s fine. I’m mainly at Home.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: why you don’t go to the park or in nature?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: you have to have a small car and it is kinda so uncomfortable me able to get into the car and do any short trip or short long trip.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: oh I’m sorry to hear that. What do you mean by small car?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yeah we have a small hatchback car which we don’t have enough space when I’m seating in it and getting into the car and the seats are not so comfortable so convenient for me to to get in the car and travel with it as a passenger.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand you don’t have enough space and your position in your poster in the car. It’s

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes exactly.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: it might be sad for you and your family, right how do you feel about it?

content: ** C: nice how does your family supporting you in this journey?

content: ** C: I understand do you feel any strong emotions and Eany like I mean, like depression, anxiety, or stressed

content: ** C: hello, how are you today?

content: ** P: hey, I’m fine thank you. How’re you?

content: ** C: I’m doing fine. It has been a while since our last visit, how have you been?

content: ** P: pretty well I have been active and have been able to enjoy my life.

content: ** C: I’m so glad to hear that. OK, what brought you here today?

content: ** P: recently I have been feeling some pain in my knee.

content: ** P: honestly not much in my daily life activity. It happens when I sit in the car as a passenger. It is OK when we are driving in the city for a short time but sitting in the car for quite a long time like more than an hour and a half or two it’s to start to be painful. We were planning to go to Germany by car this weekend, but we skipped that because I scared to have pain.

content: ** C: I understand can you explain what kind of pain do you have Anne from 0 to 10 how painful it is by meaning zero no pain and 10 is a really really high pain?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: it is a dull pain and it does not radiates down or anywhere and the pain scale or the number is like five and six.

content: ** C: I am sorry to hear that. I wonder how do you feel about this pain emotionally?

content: ** P: Kinda a lot because my daughter lives in the other city close to border, which is around three hours far and I’m not able to visit her as I used to and I have been missing my daughter!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: i’m sorry to hear that. Missing your loved ones make life less colorful.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes exactly!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: hey Mrs. F how are you doing? Good to see you again.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: thanks Dr. good to see you too.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C:how have you been your ankle after surgery and rehab?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: pretty good, I’m so happy to be able to go back and enjoy my life. recently I have been in Paris. I really enjoyed that trip.

content: ** C: nice, any issue or problem you have felt or had during this nice journey?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand why do you think you feel like that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: during the rush hour it’s usually like so crowded and I don’t have enough space in the train and of course train moves and I have less balance and that makes me uncomfortable

content: ** C: yes makes sense.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: and it is mainly because of the feeling right you do not have any pain or dysfunction.
