content: ** C: yeah I would say so.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: nice how do you feel about your life these days?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: pretty good I’m so happy and excited to be able to travel again and also be active.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: nice so glad to hear how does your family feel about this?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: great they are also excited. We are currently planning some trip around Europe to visit my daughter who is studying in Spain and also then go and see some other places.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: that sounds really nice. I’m so happy to hear that.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hello how are you doing today? It’s really good to see you again.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Thank you Dr. It’s good to see you too.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: how have you been? It has been a quite while we haven’t met. Hopefully, you could enjoy your life and I’ll be pain-free. how have you been? It has been a quite while we haven’t met. Hopefully, you could enjoy your life free of pain?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes Dr I was so happy I was able to travel. I I was really missing road trip with my family.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: glad to hear that , How was your exercise going? Have you doing them regularly?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes I was so serious about them and doing them as you exactly explained and showed me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: OK how is your hip pain from 0 to 10?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: pretty good. Maybe two.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I so glad to hear that. Are you capable of seating in a car pain-free for long period?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes I am capable of sitting in a car for quite long distances without having any pain and actually enjoy my ride.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: how do you feel about this injury of you and the treatment process?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: really good. I’m so happy to be pain-free and feel reliable on my body.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m so happy to hear that.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: thank you so much, Dr. I don’t know without your help I could’ve made it.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hello, I’m Greg, I’m your physiotherapist for today.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: My name is Sheila, nice to meet you.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How are we doing today.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Horrible. I’m so glad I finally got a meeting with you. I need serious help.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Please, tell me, what’s going on?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can’t even get my front door open.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Can you tell me more about that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I try to turn the doorknob, but my hand just won’t grip or twist.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is there also pain or any tingling sensations in the hand or wrist?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: A bit of both yes.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Have you had this for a long time?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes for 3 months

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: 3 months? That’s a long time. How have you been entering and leaving your house?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I live in a good neighborhood so I just leave the door open a crack. But unfortunately, the last time I did that someone walked inside and stole some stuff.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s awful, I’m sorry to hear that.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Thank you.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Why is it that you chose to handle your wrist pain in this manner? Were you too busy to come see a physio?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, I just didn’t think that my condition was serious enough to have looked at. People suffer from so much worse.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Not being able to turn your doorknob to enter your house is a definite red flag.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Ah, I see, so I should have come earlier?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Yes definitely. Now, let me take a look at your hand and wrist.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, please do.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hello, my name is Ben, what’s your name?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: My name is Sam

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How old are you Sam?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I saw you drive into the clinic’s parking lot, you’ve got quite a sizable vehicle.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Well, funnily enough, it’s my car I’ve been having issues with. I’ve been having issues opening and closing my car door.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s annoying. Has this always been an issue or could you first do so with ease.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Despite its size, it used to be rather easy. It’s only a bit heavier than any other car door.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What changed? Do you feel as if you have lost the strength?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: In general, yes, but I notice it most when trying to open or close my car door. With both movements I can manage the first part, but then I have to twist my shoulder in a way that makes it hard to generate enough strength to continue.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Are you capable to reposition your body to be able to produce the strength from another position?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have tried but 9 out of 10 times there are other parked cars that are in the way.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: So, how did you open and close your door today, I didn’t see when I glanced outside.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: My son is with me, he is in the waiting room. I try and drag him along everywhere I go so that he can give the extra little push or pull I need.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see. That sounds frustrating. How does it feel emotionally when something as simple as opening a car door becomes difficult?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It’s humiliating, people stare when I struggle to close my door. I never thought something so small would feel like such a hurdle.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m sorry that you have to go through that. Do you find yourself avoiding situations because of it?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Sometimes. For example, with groceries, when I see that the parking lot is full, I decide to just go back home and go another day to avoid the embarrassment of people seeing me struggle open and close my car door.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Thank you for sharing that. We’ll make it our goal to find ways to make these tasks feel manageable again.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’d really like that. I don’t want to keep feeling this limited.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi Helen, long time no see, how are the children?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hey, they’re doing good, I’m glad you were able to fit me in so late notice.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: No worries, one of my clients ended up canceling, freeing up a slot. What can I do for you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: 2 months ago, I had surgery on my shoulder and ever since then I have been having some issues.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m sorry to hear that, what happened to your shoulder?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I tore my labrum throwing a baseball.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Ouch, that must’ve been quite painful. What issues are you running into?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: To name one, it’s been difficult brushing my teeth.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What makes it that brushing your teeth is difficult.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I constantly need to take breaks. After about 30 seconds I stop and resume after another 30 seconds.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you require breaks due to pain?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I wouldn’t call it pain, it’s more like a deep fatigue in the shoulder.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: During the break, what do you do with the arm? Do you just let it hang by your side?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I prop my elbow on the sink. It helps a bit, but it still takes me double the time it used to.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How has this impacted your life?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It wears on me. It makes me feel older than I actually am. But I’m determined to keep doing it myself.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I feel for you. It is good that you’re still determined. If it’s alright with you can you take your shirt off so that I can look at the shoulder. I’ll be doing some tests

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No problem at all.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi Mr. Reynolds, how are you.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hey, Tom, I’m doing better and better every day. I’m currently also on paternity leave. My wife and I recently had a baby boy.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s wonderful news. Congratulations to both of you! I had no clue you two were expecting a child. How’s fatherhood treating you so far?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Thank you! It’s been amazing, even though the lack of sleep is definitely catching up to me, I wouldn't trade it for anything. It’s also been a perfect opportunity to spend more time with my 8-year-old son.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That is nice. What have you been doing with your 8-year-old.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: We’ve been playing a lot of baseball. Yesterday we tossed a ball back and forth in the backyard.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How did you manage?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Just some minor hiccups.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s great to hear. Could you elaborate on the hiccups? Were you not able to keep up with him?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Oh, I kept up alright. But I’ll admit, after five or six throws, my shoulder started to feel a little sore.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Did the soreness stop you from continuing?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, nothing like that. I just took it a bit slower. We still played for a good half hour.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Sounds like you're managing well, just with some mild discomfort.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Exactly. It's not ideal, but it doesn’t really hold me back. I just need to ice it afterward.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s perfectly in line with what I’d expect.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Okay, that’s good.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How are you doing emotionally? I imagine this time has brought a wide range of highs and lows.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: The shoulder injury was definitely one of the lows—I was terrified I wouldn’t be able to hold my newborn. But here I am, not only managing just fine, but even playing catch in the yard. Emotionally, I feel better than ever.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That makes me so happy. Let’s keep strengthening the shoulder so you can keep enjoying those moments with your children.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That’s the goal I want to keep playing catch with him as long as I can. And once his little brother’s old enough, I hope to do the same with him too.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hey, it’s wonderful seeing you again!

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Its nice seeing you too. How have you been?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’ve been doing well. Just busy in the clinic.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: As all ways.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How have you been since our last session? How has the gardening been?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Effortlessly, I’m a changed woman since you’ve last seen me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Please tell me more.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I managed every task without a hitch.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: How did you find turning the water faucet and pulling the hose around the flower beds?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No problem at all, my grip was strong, and the hose moved easily.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s excellent. What about those stubborn pickle jars you’ve been having trouble with. Are they easier to open now?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Absolutely, I finally have enough grip to open them properly.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s great! I’m happy you’re back doing what you love.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Me too, it hurt so much seeing my plants die merely because I couldn’t water them properly.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m so pleased for you. Let’s keep working on that grip strength to keep you at peak performance.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Sounds good to me!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hey, It’s been a while. How have you been feeling lately?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’ve been feeling well, thanks! I actually just got back from a short trip.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds great! Where did you go?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: My wife and I went to Groningen.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Nice! How was the trip?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It was really fun. It’s been a long time since I last traveled, so it felt great to get away for a bit.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s wonderful! Did you drive there yourselves?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, we took the train.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What is the most difficult part for you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: The unstability. I can't walk properly so I am scared of walking in a moving bus when they start to early.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Anything else that is bothering you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, I am way too unstable to go up and down the stairs on the bus. If I would do it, I would also be way too slow. I am just bothering all the passengers.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am sure they would understand. Why do you feel unstable?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am just so weak on my legs. It feels like they can't support my body at all.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C:How do you go from one place to another then?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Gladly my wife can drive me everywhere?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Are you two normally using the car that often?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not at all, the gas prices are horrible at the moment. We have a bit of money problems, so it is really bothering me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand. What are you worrying the most about?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That it will never get better with my weakness because I am so old and then we will struggel a lot with our money.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: We will work on your muscle strength and then this problem will not bother you anymore.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning, how are you feeling today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Like everyday, kinda alright.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Why not totally alright?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Because a friend of mine died and I want to go to the funeral, but nobody can drive me and I can't go by train.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am so sorry to hear that. Why can't you use the train?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Because the gap is too big for me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You can ask for mobility support and then the staff will provide a ramp for you.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am also not able to do it on my own.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What is the biggest problem for you when you use the train?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am dependind on someone to bring my walker with me, because I am so unstable everywhere. The gap is too big for me and my walker and I can't carry it up the stairs.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: So you need your walker for everything and the train is too much of a hustle?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, exactly.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: If you would be in the train, would you be able to move around freely?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: If you mean by freely with my walker, then yes. But at the moment it is vacation time and way too many people are in the train for me to walk with my walker.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see your point.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is it hard for you to depend on other people?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I despise it. Especially in the public, I depend on people I don't know. I just have to trust random people. They could rob me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I think most people are kind and willing to help. Robbing is an extreme example.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That is true. But still a possibility.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you have people around you that take care of you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not really, because my wife recently passed away, so I am really on my mind.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am so sorry. I will ask around the hospital, to make sure you have somebody around who looks after you.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Thanks.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It has been a bit of time since I have seen you. How are you doing?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not too bad, I would say.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You are smiling and looking so relaxed. Did you go on vacation?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Oh yes, I did. It was amazing.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Did you go by train?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No actually it was a short trip to Mallorca by plane.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: And you had no problems with using the plane?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Some, but nothing my family and I couldn't figure out together.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What kind of difficulties did you deal with?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Going on and off the plane was fine. My wife hold my arm and gave me stability and my children carried my luggage.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds good.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: But the sitting down in this tiny space and sitting for 3 hours straight was quite difficult.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: And why is that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Because of the nerve impingement, my legs constantly fall asleep when I don't change my sitting position every 15min. And in the plane I didn't have the luxus to move around a lot.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see. So what did you do to improve your numbness in the legs?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I powered through and accepted my faith.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is it annoying for you that you still have these problems now?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: A bit, but I am so glad that I could go on vacation, that this part is way too little to make me upset.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That is very good. So you have energy to continue your treatment?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Oh yes, I am so motivated, I will be without numbness in no time.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Sounds amazing. And then the next vacation can come. P. Already booked. With the help of my family I can conquer everything!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Long time no see. How is it going?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: True, I haven't seen you in a month. I am doing great. How about you?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Also good. What have you been up to?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I did some trips with my husbands with the train. Celebrating that I am almost at my old self again.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Sounds amazing! Where did you go?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Through France from the border of Germany until the border of spain.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Lovely.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How did the train rides go?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Actually really well. I can do almost everything on my own now.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Except for?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Except for going off to the train. There I still need to hold on to my husband and he carries the luggage for me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Why is that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Going down the stairs and then over the big gap is way more intimidating than going over it and then up the steps. I can't rationally explain it, but there I feel less secure and rather hold on to my love than fall.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That makes a lot of sense actually.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How is your new independancy affecting your life?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: So amazingly. I feel like myself again. I don't need my hsuband for everything and I can finally visit my daughter on my own. I just ask people to lift my luggage of the train for me and give me a hand.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds like a great solution. How is your relationship affected by that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Positively. It feels like we never fight at the moment and we are much more in harmony.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Love to hear that.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning Carla, how are you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Best day ever. I am so good. How are you?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am also doing good. What is going on that you are so great?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yesterday I used the bus and then afterwards the train completely on my own and nothing bad happened.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds amazing. Where did you go?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: To a movie theater.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: The feeling of being weak and unstable going on the bus is not there anymore?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I mean I am still a bit more worried of falling than I was before, but it is no comparison to the last weeks. I felt wuite strong and comfortable on the bus, the train I felt even better, because it does not have so many turns as the bus does.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I get what you mean. How did you deal with your luggage?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I had only a little bagpack with me and that was completly fine. Next time I will use a carry one just for practice. Then I know for sure if I am caoable of dealing with it on my own.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds like a great idea. I wish more of my patients would be so motivated.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: And now I won't be your patient that much longer.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Which is sad for me, but great for you.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Exactly.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How did your family react to your news?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: They love it. As long as I am happy, they are also happy.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Are you excited to go back to work?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, I missed having something to do and talking with my favorite colleges.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Are you worried about something?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: The only thing is that I am afraid to go to quick into my old habits and my body is not ready for that yet.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Just listen to your body and it will be fine.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, I will really give my body more attention. Thank you!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi XXX, how are you managing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Terrible. Don't even get me started.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Oh, what's happening?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: There's something wrong with my wheelchair. I have to get it fixed ASAP!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm sure it can be fixed. What's wrong with it?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It got stuck halfway constantly. I was almost thrown out because of the sudden stop!!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm very sorry about that. Were you injured?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: thank god no. If I got hurt, I'll meet you in the court.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: So sorry. Let's solve the problem before that. How long have you been using the wheelchair?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: You'd better do. Why does it matter how long I have been using it? You'll fix it no matter what.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: No worries, sir. We can find a solution in any case. I need to collect necessary information to the supplier, so that we can help you more efficiently.

content: ** P: Alright. I used it for two years. It's been working fine, but recenly I started to hear wierd noise and today got stuck.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It's marked down. I'll arrange a mechanic to you in three days. In the mean time, do you need extra help?

content: ** P: I can stay at home. It's safe for me to stay home. I can use rollator.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How would this make you feel? Staying home for a few days?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It's fine for three days, but no longer than that.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you have acompany at home?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can invite my friends to come and play Majiong. I don't mind.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning, sir. How are you feeling this afternoon?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am doing better than last week.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Lovely to hear. Is it the sunny weather that had made this week better?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: The weather is indeed perfect. But I am happy that my health is becoming better.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What do you mean by that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I started walking this week.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Has transportation become easier this week?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am still not able to go to work.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Why is that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I used to drive my car to work, but now I cannot.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I get it. What limits you from driving?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It is too painful to sit in the car. The doctor said I am not allowed to sit for too long.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you feel dizziness or pain when you are walking?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I hope you will get better soon. Can you tell me more about the pain you experience?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I get sharp pain in my hip.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Does it get better if you stand up and walk for a few minutes?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I think so.

content: ** C: Do you walk a lot?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, I am scared to leave my house. I only go to my kitchen for a cup of tea.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C:  Why are you scared?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I do not feel confident getting around.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What do you think about walking outside?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Now it is raining so much. I only leave my house if I can drive.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you have family who could drive you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, everyone is busy

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good day Anna, how are you managing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: So bad. I don't wanna talk about it. Horrible morning and even worse afternoon.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds concerning. What happened?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Something is broken in my wheelchair. And I need it! It needs to be fixed! Like now.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Did you call the people that can fix it? What exactly is broken?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, they are on their way. My brakes are broken. I am constantly moving and like that I can't chill or even get out of my wheelchair because it is not stable at all.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am sorry to hear that. Did anything happen to you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not yet, thank god. But I almost broke a glass when I couldn't stop while picking it up to drink something ebcause the chair just rolled backwards.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Glad that nothing worse happened. How long have you been using the wheelchair?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not that long. For like 3 months. It should not be broken. I still have guarantee on it.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Very good, so as soon as they fix it you will have your normal routine back. Should I help you with anything until they are here?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That would be nice. Maybe you can hold my wheelchair as long as I put makeup on so I don't accidently stab my eye with the mascara.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Of course. I will be your breaks for the next minutes, haha.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How are you feeling about the broken brakes?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It is really fucked. I am just getting used to the fact that I have to use a wheelchair as a help. And now it is broken. I just got the hang of it. And now I need help again. It is soooo annoying.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I can understand that. Do you need extra help?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That would be great. Because the mechanics didn't have the right breaks for my model so they ordered it online. They will arrive in 3 days.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I will inform the building and they will send someone to check on you every hour to see if you need help.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Thank you. That will be very annoying to wait, but I am grateful that I have the opportunity to ask for help.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Of course. I will also call your son to inform him and maybe he can help you as well.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: He is in Florida right now, if not he would already be here and we wouldn't have this conversation.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good evening. I am Darla. What is your name?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Good day Darla, I am Mino.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How was your day?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not so good. I need my walker way more than the last week.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How come?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I feel a lot weaker, I can do like 2 steps without it, but for the rest I really need it.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What exactly is feeling weak?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: My legs, especially my right leg.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Did something happen yesterday? Did you trip on your right leg?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Nothing happened, just the usual change of wheather which is bothering my old body, you know?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Ah, I understand. So you need the walker for moving everywhere?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Almost everywhere yes, the only thing I can do without it is moving around in the bathroom, because it is so tiny and also in the shower I can just sit down.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How are you feeling about your situation right now? Do you depend on help?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I love my situation. Of course I need a lot of help, but I am quite old and I accepted this fact.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Lovely, so you are feeling secure and in good hands here?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, everyone is very kind. I am used to the help by now and I love that during days like that I can ask for more help and during other days I can be a bit more independant, but someone is always near if I need something.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That is very nice to hear.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning, how are you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am good. Just a bit old and rusty.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How old are you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: 88 years old.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You look way younger.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: You are such a charmeur. Thank you.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How is your walking going? Do you still use your rollator?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It goes alright. In my appartement I am independant. But outside I need it.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Can you describe in more detail wh you need the rollator outside.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: In my appartement everything is flat and I know my way around, so I am good. But outside the ground is so different everywhere and I trip really fast. So I use it for my balance.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That is very smart. Do you use it mostly for the security of it or also for the support of your body weight.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I think mostly because I feel more stable and secure with it. I am good with my body weight.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Would you say it is also for your head?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes. Honnestly it really helps my mental state and that is why I use it outside. If I would walk without, it would be possible, but then I feel more insecure. And I am 88, so I don't wanna risk it.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You live in an elderly home. How does that make you feel.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I quite like it. My best friend lives here as well. And a lot of the people here also use a rollator, so I don't feel alone.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How does using a rollator makes you feel?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I really hated it in the beginning. I am used to walk a lot. I used to go on quite challenging hikes and it is embarrassing to not be able to do that anymore. But everybody grows old. It is normal.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: So you just needed some time to adapt to the change?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Exactly.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good evening. I am Katarina. What is your name?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Good evening Katarina, I am Carlos. How are you today?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am alright. How was your day?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not too shaby. I need my walker way less than before. A bit more strengtheing and I will be able to walk without it completly.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds amazing. What did you change in your routine?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I just included the exercises of the physio way more and now I feel so much more stable on my feet. Only my head needs to get around the fact that I can go without it.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Can you tell me at which part you are still struggeling?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Of course. When I am going to visit my daughter I will take it with me. I have to use the tram and it is way easier to get on the tram with the walker.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You said your head is a bit the problem maker. Why is that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I could go without the walker for sure. But the trust in my legs is not completly there yet. So just for my own security I take it with me, although I barely use it.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: So we will work a bit more on your leg strength to fully gain the trust back.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Sounds good.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: And then you will be also able to take the tram without your walker. P. Absolutly. That is the goal.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How did the adaption of your daily life go? Do you have support at home?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It went quite ok. I have the support of my wife. She really helped me in the beginning where I could barely do anything alone.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How do you feel, now that you gained almost all your independancy back?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I feel so lucky. I can finally help my wife cook and clean again. I can finally support her again. It was draining our relationship a lot.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I can see what you mean. So you are happy with the situation.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Absolutly. It gets better everyday and I take it day by day.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good afternoon. How are you doing?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am really good. Amazing in fact. And you?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am fine. Thanks for asking. How is the healing going? I heard all your feeling in your legs is back.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: YES. I think I am healed. Honnestly I think we will see eachother today for the last time.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That is amazing and sad at the same time. So you don't need the walker at all anymore. You feel your right leg completly?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, it is amazing. I can do everything without the walker. I feel every detail of the ground when I am barefoot. The walker is not necessary anymore.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I love to see that your nerves recovered after you had that stroke a year ago.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes. I couldn't even stand without the walker.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I remember. You really put the work in. Last time you said you still need it for the elevator and to walk on grass. How is that going?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Amazing. I left the walker at home the last couple days and just walked around. Because of all the feeling I gained back, I am my old self again. I don't feel unstable without the walker. I don't need to hold on to it. It is completly useless to me know.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That is such a great progres. Keep up with the good work and continue your exercises. Then you really will be your old self.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, I promise I will. Being independant never felt so good!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How are you feeling about going back to work, now that your body has recovered?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I am looking forward to it. I will still take it slow at the beginning, because gardening is hard on the body especially after my long break.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is there anything you worry about?

content: ** P: We have a new collegue with whom I have to work quite close with. I really hope I get along with him well and he understands my situation.

content: ** C: Have you met him before?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, only via text. But he seems like a nice person.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am sure he will understand your situation. And if not, remember communication is key! I can't misunderstand if you explain what happend to you.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: You are right. Thanks.

content: ** C: good morning I’ll be your physiotherapist today. How are you?

content: ** P: nice to meet you k.

content: ** P: yeah I'm capable of doing most of my movement and grab things but when I'm trying to twist my wrist, it's painful.

content: ** P: yes exactly but not much of a pain.

content: ** C: OK in which range you start to feel pain.

content: ** P: it's like not much for instant, for example when I am trying to use key and open my door when I am twisting my wrist with a little bit of resistant and pressure then I start to feel a little bit.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: OK that's that's good to know and also I'm wondering how do you feel emotionally generally about the whole process of your

content: ** P: so good and happy my wrist feels even better than before surgery and I can do my basic things again.

content: ** C: nice to hear that how does your family think about this?

content: ** P: they are also really happy you know the other day my grandchild was with me and we could really play and I have no problem. It makes them happy and also I'm happy.

content: ** P: I’m doing great. How are you doing Dr? Hope you are enjoying spring weather.

content: ** C: so glad to hear that. How does your rehab going?

content: ** C: I believe you’re happy about the outcome of your rehab.

content: ** P: yes I am. I am really happy about it. I feel alive again and also it’s a spring. I am much spending my time on my garden.

content: ** C: how does Mr. T feels.

content: ** P: he’s as supportive as usual, and he helps me a lot and also he is happy too because our children are also visiting us and we are really happy and excited.

content: ** C: Hey my name is Marco, I’m here to see your father.

content: ** P: Yes, please come in! My name is Samantha

content: ** C: Nice to meet you, thanks for letting me in.

content: ** C: Hey Mr. Garcia, how are you doing today?

content: ** P: Same as usual.

content: ** C: And how are you usually feeling?

content: ** P: Not great.

content: ** P: Okay

content: ** C: Are you always afraid of falling?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Pretty much. I’ve tried going alone a few steps outside the house, but I get too nervous. If my husband is not there to hold on to, I just don’t feel safe.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I get how you’re feeling. How do you feel about your inability to independently walk down the street with your walking stick?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Its obviously quite annoying having to rely on another person to do such a simple task, although, secretly I don’t mind. It gives me a good excuse to hold onto my husband.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I appreciate your honesty. It makes perfect sense to find comfort in having that support even while wanting more independence.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’m glad you understand.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi, I’m Jordan, your physiotherapist today.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hello Jordan, I’m Maria. Nice to meet you.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Nice to meet you too, Maria. Do you mind telling me your age?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Thank you. How has your day been so far?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’m a little out of breath.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I noticed you struggled a bit when you walked in with your walker, does it have anything to do with that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It does, I’ve been having issues moving around with my walker.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Please, tell me what you are struggling with.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I manage getting around, but I get wobbly on corners and when I change direction.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: So, your walker provides sufficient support, but turning and balancing remain challenging?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Exactly. I can get from the living room to the kitchen, but I have to stop and steady myself several times.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Understood. Would you say that stopping to regain balance is your main difficulty?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, I feel like I’m nearly falling every time I pivot.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How do you feel about your condition?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’m scared to death. I had a nightmare where I fell whilst using my walker. That can’t be sign that it’ll actually happen right?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m sure it was just a nightmare. With the right approach we can improve your ability to more around with your walker.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That’s all I want. I want to move more freely. I have had enough of all this worriment

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That is understandable. Let’s get started.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Agreed.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hey there, welcome! I’m Hazel, your physiotherapist.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hi Hazel, I’m Diego. Good to meet you.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Likewise, Diego. How is life.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can’t complain, what about you?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Neither can I. Before we dive in, how old are you if you don’t mind sharing?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Alright so based on your file, I can see that you had hip replacement surgery, Is that correct?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, it is.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I also noticed you came in on your crutches. Did they teach you how to use them in the hospital?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yeah, they did.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How has using them been since your hip surgery. I see in your file the surgery was 1 month ago.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I manage well. I can move around the house and even up and down the porch steps without help.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s excellent progress. Does the hip stiffness ever slow you down?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No not really. It’s mainly my palms that start hurting once I’ve been moving around with my crutches for too long.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How quickly does that pain start to arise and what do you do to make it go away.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It comes after about 20 minutes. I don’t need to do much for it to go away. Just a short rest

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: So, you’re essentially fully independent with crutches, with just minor pain in the palms after 20 minutes

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Exactly.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: With regard to the hip, I asked about stiffness but do you have any pain.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: A little yes. It’s a sort of dull aching pain that typically comes if I push too far. Nothing I can’t handle.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Despite how well you’re managing to move around with your crutches, I can imagine that you’re looking forward to the day you can go without.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yeah, it’s been way too long. I’m grateful for how well I’m doing but I can’t wait until I’m properly on my feet again.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Refresh my memory, when did the surgeon say you could go without?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: 17 days from now. I can survive another 2 and a half weeks.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That I am sure of.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning Joshua, how are you today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Good morning, I’m doing well, thanks.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: If I’m not mistaken you just got back from a ski trip, right?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That’s correct, I just got back last Tuesday.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Did you have a good time?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It was fantastic!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s great to hear. Your children also enjoyed the trip?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You didn’t have any issues whilst skiing?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No none at all, it was great being back on the Alps.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: No pain either?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Nope none at all.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Sounds like you handled everything with ease. Did you feel confident on the steeper runs?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Absolutely I never hesitated, even on the black-diamond slopes.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s excellent. Looking back to when you felt hopeless about your recovery, how would you describe how you feel now?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: In hindsight those worries were unnecessary. I think I might have been catastrophizing. Now, my confidence is at an all-time high.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m happy for you. Shall we begin our session and build on that confidence?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Let’s get started!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hello, I’m Emma, your physiotherapist, what’s your name?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’m Liam.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Nice to meet you, Liam. How has your day been?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It could be better.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Why is that? What brings you in today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have trouble using transportation.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am sorry to hear that. Could you please elaborate.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have knee pain that has been so severe, I can only travel door-to-door via taxi.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds worrisome. Could you tell me a bit more about your pain? Where is it and what exacerbates it.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: So, it’s my left knee, and every time I put weight on it, there is a severe stabbing pain. It feels as if its deep inside the knee.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What would you rate that pain on a scale from 0-10, 10 being the worst pain imaginable.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It’s around an 8.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I can imagine you’re feeling quite frustrated by this pain and the inability to travel independently.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yeah it really is, I just want to know what’s wrong with my leg and how I can fix it. I would do anything for that to happen.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I completely understand. We’ll get to the bottom of your knee pain.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: You’re a life saver

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good afternoon Mrs. Adams, my name is Greg.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Oh please, call me Marguerite.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Marguerite, got it. Before we get started, I notice that your GP isn’t registered in our system, do you happen to know his name?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes of course, its Dr. Jacobs

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Alright, perfect, I added it to your file. What brings you in today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Unfortunately, ever since October, I haven’t been able to travel to the city like I used to.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Before October, how did you travel into the city?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I would take the tram close to my house.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What makes it that you can no longer do that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I can, but no longer alone. I am dependent on my partner. He has to help me board and find a seat.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see, what part of the journey do you struggle with most?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Climbing the three steps onto the tram is painful, and I’m unsteady once I’m inside.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds frustrating. How does relying on someone else every day make you feel?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It makes me feel a bit guilty but at the same time a little embarrassed.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I can understand that but do note that it is nothing to be embarrassed about. Tell me, are you at all afraid you are going to fall?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Very. A friend of mine recently fell and broke her hip. At the moment she can’t do anything at all anymore. God forbid that happens to me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Thank you for sharing

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi, I’m Jenna, your physiotherapist, what’s your name?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’m Alex.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Nice to meet you, Alex. How has your day been so far?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It’s been alright.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What brings you in today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’ve been having trouble catching the city bus to work.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Why is that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: The route the bus takes is extremely bumpy and every bump, or even a sudden stop, sends a jolting pain through my lower back.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is it focal or does the pain also radiate to any other locations in the body?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Its purely in the lower back

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Could you rate this pain from 0, no pain at all, to 10, the worst pain ever?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I would give it a 4 or a 5. The pain is manageable with pain killers, and albeit its annoying, halfway I have to transfer buses, which gives my back a break.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What kind of painkillers do you take and do you take them every morning in anticipation of the bumpy bus ride?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I take 2 paracetamols every morning before I go to work.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Do you ever feel frustrated or discouraged traveling to work.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Honestly yes but I need the money so I never take any days off.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Has your back pain affected your confidence in getting around independently?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, I wouldn’t say so. I get to where I need to be but and I’m confident in my ability to do so. The journey is simply a nuisance and frustrating.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I know what you mean. I’ll take a look at your back and afterwards we’ll come up with a treatment plan to solve this issue.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Alright.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hello Jane, it’s good to see you again, how are you today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hi, I’m doing alright, thanks.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How has your week been since our last session?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It’s been busy but I’ve been managing.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Have you been facing any troubles taking the bus to work?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: A bit, but I can tell that things are going in the positive direction.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: What troubles did you run into?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: The mornings are always busy. Usually I stand for the first 10 minutes on the bus, but after the train station stop, I can sit for the remaining 15. Monday that wasn’t the case.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How did your body respond to that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Surprisingly I managed until the end of the ride however I felt It a lot in my body.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Where in your body did you feel it?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: My legs and lower back were sore for about 3-4 days.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How do you feel about this experience.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: The soreness was irritating but I was happy to see that I am capable of enduring the entire ride. I just wish I didn’t get so sore afterwards.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m glad you see this as a positive experience. I believe with some muscular endurance training we can smoothen your bus journeys within no time.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: That sounds amazing!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning Joshua, how are you doing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hi Michael, I’m doing good, how about yourself?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am also good, thanks for asking! Did you have a good holiday?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yeah it was great! The family and I flew to Malta and took a ferry to one of the nearby islands.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That sounds wonderful. Did you have much trouble with the plane or ferry?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It all went swimmingly!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How did your new ACL hold up during the trip.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Works like a charm, had no pain whatsoever.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That’s great to hear! You didn’t get any swelling in the leg when you were in the plane?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: A little bit but no more than any other person. I was by the emergency doors so I had the leg room to stretch and move around a bit.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Some extra leg room is always nice. Sounds like you had a very nice trip.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It was great

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I can imagine this trip boosted your spirits.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: 100 percent. I was having some serious doubts, I didn’t believe that the ligament would survive the trip. I was close to canceling. I guess I’m much more capable than I thought.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That you are. Shall we get started with our session? There’re still a few extra degrees of flexion we can get out of that knee.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Let’s do it!

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Hi, how are we doing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Not so well.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Would you tell me more about it?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I feel weak. I couldn't get out of my bed this morning. I had to wait for the nursing assistant to help me.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm sorry about that. Could you get up with help?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, but I don't like it. I don't want to rely on others. I need to be able to do it myself.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I do feel for you. I'm sure it'll get better. Could you describe what you have to do to get up from bed?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I need to move myself towards the edge of the bed first, and then I can push the button to lift up my upper body into a sitting position and then I can transfer to my wheelchair.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see that. At which step do you find difficult?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I struggle at every step if I'm on my own. It's impossible for me to get up by myself.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see. Do you have a helper at home?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, I have one since last week, but it's very expensive. I wonder if there's anything I can do.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: There are things we can still improve, I'm sure. How do you feel about your current status?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It's terrible. Living a life relying on others. I wish I could end this.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm sorry to hear that. Do you have family around you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: No, I'm all alone. My partner passed away last month. I shall go with him soon enough.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm truly sorry for your loss. It must be tough for you. May I arrange some visits for you even if it's not a family visit?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I'm not sure if it's gonna help, but OK.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning Mr. J, how are you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Who is that speaking?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: This is Sandy, calling from the hospital. Nice to meet you.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Oh, why? From the hospital? Did someone go to the hospital?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Yes, Mr. J, you were in the hospital 3 months ago. Now you're home. I'm calling to check how you're doing.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I was in the hospital? I don't recall that. What do you wanna know?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Have you met any difficulties recently, with transfering, with eating, with showering?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I don't know. I can eat, I can take shower. No problem. What do you mean by transfer?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good to know that eaing and showering are not an issue. Transfering means, for example, from wheelchair to sofa, from wheelchair to toilet, are you able to do that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Oh, I'm very strong. Of course I can do everything.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm glad to hear you're feeling strong. Have you noticed there are some moments that you can't do it by yourself?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I don't know why. Sometimes I peed in my pants, and I'm not sure what happened.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see. How do you like your living status now?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Oh, everything's great. Only wierd things are happening sometimes. Lat night, I was patroling at school, and then somehow I was home.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: How do you feel about that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Just wierd. But that's life wierd things happen.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: You're right.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: What? Who are you?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good afternoon, Mrs. Liu, how are you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Oh, nice to have you calling. I'm good, and you?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I'm well. Thanks for asking. How's life?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: As usual. I live with my big family. We have a helper at home. Nothing to complain about.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That's good to know. Let me know if you meet any difficulties.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Just one thing maybe. I stuggle a bit with moving from chair to chair.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Can you tell me more about it?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes. At home, we have big table, where we gather to eat dinner. And around the table, there are high wooden stools, without backrest. Everyday before dinner, I sit on the first stool and then I move to the one closer to the wall, so that my husband can sit on the one outside. But I always find it inconvenient.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Did you need help when moving?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It depends on how the stools are placed. Sometimes it's easy for me to scoop in, sometimes no. And I can't move the stools while bending.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Why not?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It's difficult for me to bend, and the stools are heavy, I don't think I can move them anyway.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Thank you. Now I get the full picture. How do these difficulties in life make you feel?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I'm used to it. I had an even worse situation only one year ago.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It's nice to know that you take it optimistically.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Yes, if you have experienced worse. I was on tubes last year, and now I can eat by myself. You'd have been satisfied with what you have after what happened.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: It's inspiring to see how far you've come. How do do you feel about that?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Everybody says it's miracle. And I agree. I'm happy with what I have.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Good morning, I am Rihanon and I will help you today. What is your name?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Hello Rihanon, I am Margret.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Nice to meet you. How are you doing today.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: It is not a bad day. I have a bit of problems getting from sitting into laying but other than that I fell wuite okay.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: That is lovely to hear Margret. Would you mind telling me what makes it difficult for you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Of course not. I am really uncomfortable with bending my upper body, so going to on side is quite harsh on my body and I don't know how I can lay down in any other way.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Is it more the bending to the front, side ot back that is harsh on your body?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I think the bending to the side is the most problematic. As soon as I do it, I get scared and just tense up.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: Great that you can describe it that detailed. So we will work on that today and we will try to get the trust in your body back. Sounds good?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: Sounds amazing.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: hey Mrs. J how are you doing today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: not so well I believe I’m a steal under influence of Anastasia.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: how was your surgery?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: luckily it it went well, but it was a long surgery

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m glad to hear surgery went well.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: me too, doctor said they could take the tumour out.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: how does your body feel after surgery?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I feel so weak I’m not moving that much and having a difficulties even rolling in the bed.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: why do you think you cannot roll? Is it painful?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes my wound is really open and that’s something which is painful and also my muscles are feeling so weak.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I see do you need help to roll or move around in the bed?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes I usually I ask for help.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: how do you feel emotionally after surgery?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: generally happy because I could get rid of the two more but my current situation not be able to move. It’s really frustrating.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes I understand. It’s really hard to not be able to move.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: yes exactly I’m generally an active person and this situation is kind of difficult.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: but you see the whole situation as a positive thing right because you know you will be better and able to move again soon.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: yes hundred percent I know as soon as I will go home, I will be more active and hopefully with some Physio sessions I can get my strength back.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: exactly I like the mindset and you are quite positive about the situation. That’s nice.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: hello Mr. L good to see you how have you been?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: hello Dr thanks I’m doing fine. You know life is labor challenging these days.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: understand how is your day going? Is it under control nowadays?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes my GP has a strict treatment for me and we could control it.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m glad to hear that and of course it’s sad to see your foot should be amputated, but I’m sure it will be adjusted an adopted a new life.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I hope so it has not been so easy in the last couple of months.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: yes I cannot imagine how how is life going? Do you have any difficulties these days in related to moving from surface to surface and so on

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes for sure it is really hard to move from my wheelchair to bed  or toilet. I constantly need help. But rolling in the bed it’s fine.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand it’s difficult to do this, but would you please explain what kind of difficulty do you have?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: obviously I’m an old man and I’m not as strong as befor. This life it’s new for me and I’m not used to that. I’m struggling with how to manage how to move. I do not feel so strong.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: OK you mainly think you’re not get used to and not found the way to do your stuff and of course you need a new set of skills and maybe strength on your upper body more than before.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes I think so.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I am wondering to what extend the situation affect your emotions?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: a lot I have been always an active person and independent and nowadays, I am truly relies on my wife and nurse it is really hard.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: last time you told me you booked time with psychologist how does it going?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: going really good. My psychologist helped me to understand my emotions and feelings, and see situations from different angle.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: and you feel it helps or it works?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yeah I was talking about it with my wife yesterday. Definitely feel seeing psychologist. It’s really helping me to keep my emotions regulated and also helps me mentally.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: so glad to hear that.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: hello how are you doing? I am D and your physiotherapist today.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: hi D, I’m doing fine thank you how are you?

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m doing fine. How can you? How can I help you today?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: going fine life is challenging sometimes and some certain activity for me. As an old people it makes it makes life even more challenging.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I understand that would you please let me know what do you mean by challenging life?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: sure I have I feel weak on my arms and since I am using wheelchair, it it is sometimes difficult for me to move from one from bed to the wheelchair or from wheelchair to the toilet, but otherwise it’s fine.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: OK is it happened in your daily life or it’s just some certain situations?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: mostly some certain situations I’m quite comfortable at home because I because we adjusted everything to my circumstances, such as my bad he the toilet height, but sometimes outside in in the mall or in the library, it’s become difficult.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: and would you explain what do you mean by difficult?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have hard time moving from surface or from my wheelchair to my bed and toilet without receiving help or using my Lyft.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: how does depending on your age and someone makes you feel about your situation?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: certainly not so confidence and since I’m limited and always need to be concerned about where I’m going it makes my life little bit more isolated.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: do you have someone who is emotionally and mentally supporting you in this?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I have a social caregiver who visiting me every other day. He’s a really nice person we get along well and sometimes we have a nice chat yeah nothing more than that.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: and you think about the whole situation in a positive way or you don’t like it and you feel under pressure or anxious or any other strong emotion you are experiencing?

speaker: patient
content: ** P:  I guess I’m a little bit depressed and my confidence is not there anymore since I always need help for the basic thing and also I’m not as socialized before because I cannot like hang out and do some certain activities.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: do you feel talking to some expert would help you?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I don’t know. I have been thinking maybe visit some psychologist and talk about my situation yeah but I have not done anything so far.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: hey Mr. L. It has been a long time and you look so good. How are you doing?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: hey Jay, I’m doing good. How have you been? Yes, it has been a long time.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: as I said, you look so different and unhappy yeah tell me more. How is life these days?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: quite good. I really adopted the new life after my amputation, and I would say life is as beautiful as before.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: oh so good I’m so happy to hear.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: OK tell me more about like that to extend this new life is challenging you or everything is fine.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I would say all good. The rehab program is helped me to build up my strength, and I am more comfortable with moving from places to my wheelchair and back. But the only thing would be, it would be rolling in my bed.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: interesting what do you mean by rolling in your bed is challenging?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: you know it’s not something really serious. I have a really soft mattress which is like I’m really sank in it and rolling in that mattress. It’s a little bit challenging. That’s the only thing.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: ok, then it’s not something serious, right.

speaker: patient
content: ** P:  yes, it’s all fine.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: and how do you feel emotionally after all you have been go through

speaker: patient
content: ** P: you have been seen me in the early days and how depressed. I had a hard time to accept my new life, but now everything is good.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: it’s so nice to hear that and I’m pretty sure your family is also really appreciating.

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes my family is so happy. We are spending more time together. I must say I’m so grateful for you my physiotherapist, and also my psychologist who helped me through this journey to get my life back.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: you’re welcome we were we are here to help you, but you did the job we were just with you.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: good morning good to see you, Mr. Bea after a while how are you doing?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: hello Dr good to see you too. I’m so happy to see you back. I’m doing well.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: glad to hear that how was your treatment process going?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I would say going great. I am not dependent on any first aid anymore. I can easily move from my wheelchair to my bed and toilet.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: oh so glad to hear that that’s a long progress

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes it is. I’m so happy about it and thank you for helping me this.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: OK and what I understand is you feel strong again on your on your body to be able to move from surfaces to the other?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: yes exactly. I was doing your exercises and I could improve my core stability and my arm to be able to move and I am definitely more stable than before.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: great and you’re not using your lift anymore or asking any help from someone?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: I’m all independent now and I’m still keep doing your exercise exercises.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: so glad to hear that, how does your emotions about this?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: good I feel reborn and I feel so confidence and a capable. I don’t feel any need or help from someone which makes me feel so happy you know in my age. It’s so important to be independent..

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I agree how does Mrs. Bea think about this situation?

speaker: patient
content: ** P: she is happy about it too. You know it makes me happy to see. She’s also doing well and she do not need to be worry about me all the time and that’s something makes me happy and motivated too to keep going and not stop.

speaker: doctor
content: ** C: I’m so glad to hear that
